I watched many YouTube videos on how to do it correctly. The key is to heat the water in a pot to 190 deg. And let it cool to 185 then start the slow pouring process. Need a thermometer for sure at first but could go from eyeballing the water bubbles after a few makings.

Pouring the water slow and letting it drain is also key. Thatâ€™s how the magic happens. So so so worth the wait for a beautifully luxurious tasting cup of coffee to start your day!!

Try it. You wonâ€™t be disappointed!

title: This thing brews fast--
body:
This is an interesting little brewer (500ml/17oz) that's both functional and attractive. It is a metal filter system, so you should expect fines and oil in the cup, regardless of what manufacturers say about it being similar to paper-filtered coffee. That being said, the fines are minimal for a metal filter system. That difference in taste and texture is why I bought this brewer, and something you should at least expect, if not enjoy if you are considering purchasing one. Your brewing technique will also have to change if you are used to brewing with paper, but I think it's easier to get it right than paper

Things to like:
-the coffee is full-bodied and textural
-the carafe shape does a nice job of trapping fines in the bottom during the pour because of the break angle between the bottom and top sections
-the opening on the 500ml(17oz) brewer is the perfect size for a plastic V60-2 dripper if you just want to use the carafe
-the upper part of the carafe will hold a ceramic dripper cone like a Loveramics or Origami dripper with room to brew about 500ml
-the carafe feels high quality
-it's easy to operate

Things to dislike:
-the filter does not have much room for coffee; I like to brew about 16g to 350g (weak, I know) and the filter is about half full at that point
-the filter feels cheap compared to the carafe; it's easy to see why looking at the price of something like the Abel Kone or Kinto Slow; the performance is still good
-it would be very difficult to get your hand inside to wipe with a cloth if you like to clean by hand
-the neck where you grip is rather large and could prove difficult to hold for smaller hands
-the pouring, while not messy, leaves a little to be desired; you have to pour fairly steeply

Silly gripes:

title: My first ever Pour Over Coffee Pot & I absolutely ***LOVE*** it!
body:
Iâ€™ve been wanting a part of a coffee maker for a while now. Finally decided to purchase one for my birthday and so glad I decided on this one. I went back-and-forth here on Amazon searching for the best pour over coffee maker, comparing all the reviews and this one had the best of everything. Just made my 1st cup of coffee, itâ€™s absolutely delicious and I just had to write a review immediately afterward. The Bodum Pour Over CoffeePot is stylish, sturdy, comfortable to hold when hot and cold and itâ€™s super easy to take apart and clean. I had two videos to upload but Amazon only allows one, so trying to include as much info as possible. I used 12oz of water and 2.5 level scoops of coffee for my xl coffee cup. I would suggest grinding your own beans if you have a coffee grinder. I use the prepackaged Gevalia Papua New Guinea coffee which is a fine ground. Took about 5-6 min to brew. Side noting that the coffee will not be too hot by the time brewing has completed due to the length of time it takes for fine grounds to brew. A slightly larger ground coffee bean would work best and would be hotter when finished. I add milk to my coffee, so that does tend to cook it down slightly also. Overall, Iâ€™m extremely pleased with this pot and the delicious cup of coffee it produced.

Comparing my experience to the other reviewerâ€™s, the Glass is sturdy, itâ€™s not thin at all, so as long as you donâ€™t manhandle it roughly, you should be just fine. The cork is very comfortable in your hand, protecting your hand from the heat of the coffee and it is NOT hot at all to hold. It comes apart easily, simply squeeze the button, gently loosen the leather strap, and it slides right over. The cork pops right off, wash with soapy hot water and dry. Cork pops right back on and stays in place while you use two hands to replace the leather strap and re-tighten in place. Love this pour over coffeepot and highly recommend it. title: Favorite way to brew coffee now.
body:
I ended up getting the bigger version, but my review I think remains the same:
This part isnt about the item itself, but rather how it was shipped from Amazon,which is one reason I'm returning it- when we received this, it was in an amazon box with other items, and it was not in its actual product box at all, nor was it even wrapped, I'm a bit uncomfortable with this because this item is 100% sold in a dedicated item box ( again, we ended up buying the bigger version from a physical store. )
That being said,
The item itself is fantastic,
It's the only way I make hot coffee now,
I read a lot of reviews making comments about the flavor and fullness of the brew, and I 100% agree there,
It was mentioned in different reviews that the essential oils from the coffee are able to stay in your brew since you're not brewing through a paper filter,
You can see a slight " oil" film when you swish the coffee inside the carafe,
The flavor and smoothness of the coffee made with this is unbeatable in my opinion, a lot of coffee I've had, no matter it's brew method ( with the exception of cold brew ) there's always the bitterness that just cuts through and stays on your tongue, some people like this, I don't,
The coffee from this has a very nice and smooth feeling, and is definitely not as bitter nor does it leave as sharp of an after taste.
The first cup I brewed from this, I was floored by how good it was, almost convinced it was just the cream and then realizing the only difference between the day before and this cup, was the brew method - but I even tried it hot and black, and it was still 10/10.

I make coffee every night before bed, and with the 34oz there's enough left in the carafe after making a 20oz mug, that I can let it cool and pour the rest into ice cubes to freeze over night and have coffee ice cubes set for the morning.
Before this, my preference was french press - but the cleaning process was always dreadful.
This item is so easy, the grounds come off the stainless steel filter like butter ( and you can easy reuse them in cleaning & skin care products, or even in your garden and for pests around the home. )
I would recommend having a brush to clean this with, but all in all I'm definitely happy with the item itself.
10/10 would recommend.

title: Discription is deceptive
body:
This is NOT a double wall glass canister. The cork is double wall. That is why the cork is required to keep your hands from burning on the thin wall glass. If you love hot coffee and are counting on the canister of keeping your extra cups hot.......you may wish to rethink this one.
Pros: 1.) Inexpensive 2.) If cute is your thing, this is cute.
Cons. 1.) glass canister will not keep coffee hot for long. A thin wall glass couple with a top cover(?) that will allow great amounts of heat to escape. I really see no need for the top cover. Plus the pour over method allows heat to escape while pouring. It is all a down side for hot coffee lovers.
This is just another tool for the coffee toolbox. Flavor? It's all on the pour over knowledge and other tools, like the coffee scale. The Bodum pour over has nothing to do with flavor...it is all in your knowledge of what your taste is, preparation and performance of the pour.
2.) As others have said, my preference is using a filter. That I did find makes my coffee more suitable to my taste as it does collect the very fines that will pass with out the paper filter.
Overall, I take off 2 stars for deceptive advertising and one star for a poor design on the lid.
I will continue to use this during the summer months as I think even the second cup will keep me satisfied. Only making 1 cup vs 2 cups does not effect an increase in the heat of the coffee.
I may go back to the drip method during the winter, plus having more knowledge of grind to water mixture and the amount of time needed to brew just may make my drip maker better enough to forget the pour over..............time will tell. Hope this helps you hot coffee lovers ))))))

title: Cute, but not practical
body: While this is cute as can be sitting on my kitchen counter, it's almost useless. The pros of this are it saves electricity because you don't have a coffee maker plugged in all the time, and if you have a gas stove you can heat water that way. As for the cons it takes forever to make a cup of coffee. Forget this if you want to get up in the morning and have a quick cup of coffee. You are told in the video to pour the water over the grounds slowly and by the time you are finished pouring (can't pour all at once) the coffee is nearly lukewarm. Then there's the matter of the grounds seeping through the filter. Not tasty. If you try to use a filter it takes twice as long to seep through. I have had mine almost a month now and kept thinking I'd figure out a faster way to use it, but so far nothing has helped. The product is as advertised, but the actual coffee produced is weak and not flavourful. If you like body and flavour to your coffee, then cannot recommend getting this.

I used the same brand of coffee and prepared it with 4 different methods: French press, mocha pot, percolator, and this pour over coffee maker. the mocha pot makes really strong, concentrated espresso. the percolator and French press both make nice, well-rounded brews that are bold but not too strong.

This pour over coffee maker brews extremely weak coffee though. the beans and the water simply do not come into contact with one another for long enough.

For reference I used 2 Tbs of a finely ground coffee (Brazilian Pilao, Extraforte) per 6oz of water for each method.

I went back-and-forth here on Amazon searching for the best pour over coffee maker, comparing all the reviews and this one had the best of everything. The Bodum Pour Over CoffeePot is stylish, sturdy, comfortable to hold when hot and cold and itâ€™s super easy to take apart and clean. I had two videos to upload but Amazon only allows one, so trying to include as much info as possible. I used 12oz of water and 2.5 level scoops of coffee for my xl coffee cup. I would suggest grinding your own beans if you have a coffee grinder. I use the prepackaged Gevalia Papua New Guinea coffee which is a fine ground. Took about 5-6 min to brew. Side noting that the coffee will not be too hot by the time brewing has completed due to the length of time it takes for fine grounds to brew. A slightly larger ground coffee bean would work best and would be hotter when finished. I add milk to my coffee, so that does tend to cook it down slightly also. Overall, Iâ€™m extremely pleased with this pot and the delicious cup of coffee it produced.

Comparing my experience to the other reviewerâ€™s, the Glass is sturdy, itâ€™s not thin at all, so as long as you donâ€™t manhandle it roughly, you should be just fine. The cork is very comfortable in your hand, protecting your hand from the heat of the coffee and it is NOT hot at all to hold. It comes apart easily, simply squeeze the button, gently loosen the leather strap, and it slides right over. The cork pops right off, wash with soapy hot water and dry. Cork pops right back on and stays in place while you use two hands to replace the leather strap and re-tighten in place. Love this pour over coffeepot and highly recommend it. title: Great tasting coffee, great looking product, easy to use.
body:
So far so good. I'll be honest, I was skeptical at this kind of brewing method ever since they started to pop up at designer coffee shops everywhere, but my moka pot went caput recently and I thought I'd change brewing methods to keep this year interesting, so I bought this and have not been dissapointed.

4 stars for desing - I bought the 17 oz one because I think it looks the best (nice and cute). The corck around the waist could be a little bit thinner I think, but other than that I love it. Note, that this size is good for 2 (size tall in sbucks terms) cups of coffee. You can get away with three, but you'll be labeled stingy.
5 stars brewing - It comes with a filter basket which has thus far been excellent at making sure no debris comes into the coffee (just a trace of soot). It even comes with a little cap that you can put on it after brewing so that the coffee can remain hot for a little while longer.
5 for taste - I'm not coffee nut, but as far as tastes goes, it definately produces a great tasting cup IMO. I've never gotten bitter coffee out of it (even when using weeks old, stale, store bought preground beans lol). When I use quality/fresh beans, the output is sublime (better than the moka pot).

I dont find there is a significant difference between this and an automated drip machine, but, I find this to be a great way to avoid dedicating a portion of counter space to bulky machines while at the same time produce great coffee!

title: Awesome coffee!
body:
I was looking into a more affordable and smaller version of a Chemex-style coffee maker, because I love how pour-over coffee tastes. I've used a french press for years, and using the Bodum pour-over coffee maker wasn't too far off from how I usually make my coffee. I love that it comes with a metal/mesh filter, because I don't have to buy a specific kind of filter, and it is zero waste.

I start by heating my water (we use reverse osmosis water) to around 200 - 205 degree F. If you don't have a thermometer, just heat to boil, then turn off heat and wait a few minutes. Then, I weigh out 25 grams of medium-coarse coffee which I grind fresh in a manual burr grinder (do not use a mechanical grinder! It creates heat in grounds and also does not grind it evenly). If you don't have a kitchen scale, this ends up being around 2.5-3 tablespoons.

Next, I use about 15 g of water for every 1 g of ground coffee. This ends up being 375 g hot water for 25 g of coffee. I pour over a bit of hot water over all the grounds to "bloom" the coffee, then begin pouring over the rest of the 375 g of water (I do this with the coffee maker sitting on my kitchen scale to measure).

Once the water has passed through (should take around 3 minutes), the coffee is ready! It takes a bit more effort than french press, but I love how it turns out.

I love the size of this maker, since I am the only one who drinks coffee in my apartment and do not heed a huge capacity.

title: Really good for puerh tea
body:
I've been looking for a vessel to brew puerh tea, and this is perfect.

I get puerh in the little tuo chas (solid small balls of fermented tea leaves). Those need to be soaked a bit before they will fall apart, and then they need to be rinsed in warm water before the hot water brew. All of this makes it a pain to use a dangling tea infuser, or a typical top-of-the-cup tea strainer.

I put the tuo cha loose in the bottom of this carafe, get it good and wet, and wait a while for it to fall apart (how long depends on the age of the ball). Then I carefully pour out any remaining water - the tea will stay behind in the curve of the side. I do this two more times - once to rinse, and once to brew. I use a Chemex glass lid to keep the heat in during brewing, and to save the leaves for the next brew. (I don't use the Bodum filter or lid).

This isn't what the carafe was designed for, but it works.

title: Two days and several cups of great coffee later....

I have had this little coffee maker for two days and I am enamored with it. It looks cool, doesn't take up much counter space, it's simple...but mostly importantly the coffee is great. I have used many pour-over brewers and french presses, but thus far this is my favorite. Why do I like it?
1. Simplicity

3. No need to buy filters--there is a minimal residue at the bottom of the pot, but you also get all the oils and flavors that should be in coffee
4. Filter is mostly stainless steel, minimal plastic
5. It's small--it doesn't take up counter space, which is important if you have a small kitchen
6. The coffee tastes great
7. Did I mention the coffee tastes great?
The only drawback could be the cork, in the long run. I clean it without removing it (the instructions say to remove it prior to cleaning), because I wash it by hand. The cork is in two pieces, which fall away once the leather cord is removed. So, if that sounds annoying to you, get the model with the rubber wrap.
